results.description:
***NOTE:  ADEQUATE WATER SUPPLY & BOWL ARE REQUIRED FOR YOUR DOG.***

Thursday will be 72 degrees and mostly cloudy at 8:00 a.m.  Let's start early  before it gets to be "Feels Like 82" a couple hours later. Great day for a doggy walk around the lake :)  .

Please look carefully at the instructions and map below to find out where to park and meet for the walk!

Lake Kittamaqundi, the downtown heart of Columbia. For many years, the path only went only part-way around the lake. But this fall, the Columbia Association completed the circuit and we can now walk around the entire lake along a new paved path!

This walk is very flat, only one gentle hill, and 1.5 miles around. We'll pass by the People Tree, the lakefront stage, and long-established Columbia restaurants like Clyde's and Tomato Palace.


You will basically head for the new Whole Foods of Columbia (added in Fall 2014), across from the Columbia Mall. However, we will park and meet in the lower lot, down the hill, and to the right of Whole Foods (as you look at it from the front.) This is actually the parking lot for the new Haven on the Lake spa. Please park in the area furthest from the spa entrance, as shown on the map below, so that we are closest to the trail and won't get in the way of the spa clients.


SAFETY & COURTESY

Please arrive early, to allow the dogs time to sniff and form their pack. We will leave on time.  If you can't make it please change your RSVP promptly, or leave a comment.  We'll turn to the right on the trail (counter clockwise) so you'll know where to find us if you arrive late.  


Please bring water for yourself & your dogs.  We're trying to avoid sharing water on the trail to prevent the chance of spreading the New Dog Flu.

If you see joggers or bikers, please shout "ON YOUR LEFT" to keep the dogs safe from being trampled, and to protect others from tripping on our animals.

PLEASE READ:

Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for friendly people with friendly dogs to meet people with similar interests on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that: 

•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests. 

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a 6-foot fixed leash (non-retractable) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)

 Looking forward to seeing everyone again!  


                                                                       Photos by J. Ameen-Lee
results.how_to_find_us: See directions & map below.  Park  closest to the woods in the shade by the trail; we will meet there.
results.name: Lake Kittamaqundi 8:00 a.m. morning trot

During the recent attack on Nerosyan, Pathfinders sought out a local venture-captain to aid in the city’s defense. results.description: The Speculative Fiction Critique Circle normally meets every 2nd and 4th Thursday at BSFS. We're a friendly, but very focused group of writers who go in-depth to critique the works we bring in. We never get personal, but we will provide deep, honest feedback. We've had many stories workshopped here published professionally, and our goal is to keep that happening by making stories as strong and sharp as they can be. If you're going to present, bring 6 to 8 copies of a piece up to 2,500 words. For those with longer works, serialization is common. Of course, anyone who just wants to sit in, not present, and talk writing with us, is more than welcome to come by and do just that.
results.name: Critique Circle For Writers

results.description:
Drinking Skeptically is an informal social event designed to promote fellowship and networking among skeptics, critical-thinkers, and like-minded individuals. Drinking Skeptically provides an opportunity for skeptics to talk, share ideas (and yes, drink) in a casual, relaxed atmosphere. We discuss the issues of the day and whatever else is on our minds. But most of all, we have fun while promoting skepticism, science, and rationality. Don't drink? Don't let that stop you from joining us! Some of the world's most famous skeptics are teetotallers, and we are happy to have you! Remember that drinking skeptically means drinking responsibly. If there's one thing science has taught us, it's the effects of alcohol on the human body. To learn more about Drinking Skeptically see www.drinkingskeptically.org

The area set aside be the establishment for our group is not wheelchair accessible. The venue has no age restriction for the duration of our event.

CFI-DC encourages people with disabilities to participate in its programs and activities. If you anticipate needing accommodations or have questions about physical access you may email sdavis [at] centerforinquiry [dot] net in advance of the event.
results.name: CFI–DC Drinking Skeptically Baltimore Meetup

results.description:
Movie: Faith of Our Fathers

6:40 PM showtime

Meet Bobbi in the theatre lobby between 6:25 and 6:30 pm.   You can purchase tickets when you arrive at the theatre, no need to purchase them in advance.

With the Vietnam War raging in 1969, two young fathers report for duty. A man of great faith and a doubtful cynic. A quarter-century later, their sons, Wayne and John Paul, meet as strangers.

Guided by handwritten letters from their fathers from the battlefield, they embark on an unforgettable journey to The Wall—the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, D.C. Along the way, they discover the devastation of war cannot break the love of a father for his son. FAITH OF OUR FATHERS: a story of fatherhood; a journey of brotherhood.

Starring Stephen Baldwin, Kevin Downes, David A.R. White, Rebecca St. James, with Si Robertson and Candace Cameron Bure, FAITH OF OUR FATHERS is in theaters now.


Link to trailer:  http://faithofourfathersmovie.com/

This is the theatre behind Home Depot off Snowden River Parkway in Columbia.

results.description:
Last month we met to learn about Lunas (pictured here) and other moths. Many who attended took home eggs and larvae to raise at home. This month it's time to meet again so we can swap stories and moths.  Those who ended up with females--come and get a male.  Those who ended up with males--come and get a female.  Several people will be on hand to talk about the life cycle of Lunas, as well as other moths found around Maryland.  If you missed last month's meeting, join us.  There will be plenty to learn, and you can take home a cocoon, egg, or larva to raise at home.

Nick will bring lots of Polyphemus moths in their first instar (growth stage).  If you would like to take one home, find a good source of ash, birch, grape, hickory, maple, oak, or pine.  If you would like to raise Lunas, find a good source of sweet gum or Black Walnut.  Bring a clipping with you along with a container. (If you don't know how to identify these trees, I will be posting a picture of sweet gum soon. Perhaps someone can add a picture of the other trees as well? We will also bring examples to the meeting.) We will show you how to set them up, and what to expect in the coming weeks. You will need a five-gallon (or larger) aquarium with a tight-fitting screen on top, or something similar to house them once you get home.

Even if you don't want to raise these little guys and gals, come out and enjoy an evening of learning about Maryland moths.

This will be an informal meeting. Be prepared to ask questions and go with the flow of the evening.

Cost: FREE

I am trying a new format for this meetup:

This format for the 2nd Thursday ONLY:

Each session should be divided into two groups. Each signer determines where they fit:

JOEL and KEVIN

results.description:
WELCOME TO PATUXENT TOASTMASTERS CLUB

The mission of the Patuxent Toastmasters Club is to provide a supportive and positive learning experience in which members are empowered to develop communication and leadership skills, resulting in greater self-confidence and personal growth. 

Toastmasters International has awarded PATUXENT TOASTMASTERS with the SELECT DISTINGUISHED CLUB AWARD for club excellence in 2013/2014.

Congratulations to Brahma Sen for completing the requirements of the Advanced Communicator Bronze!

Congratulations to Linda Thompson and Jon Hansen for completing the requirements for the Competent Leadership Award!

Congratulations to our club winners for the Toastmasters International and Table topics competition.

Emily Livelsberger placed first and Greta Swanson place 2nd in our club Table Topics Contest.  Emily went on to place 2nd at the Division 56 competition.  Jim Bartlett placed first and Ken Scaffer placed 2nd in our club International Speech Contest.

Congratulations to Greta Swanson and Linda Thompson for completing the requirements of the Competent Communications Award!

Awards presented by Diane Heath, ACS, Division 56 Governor

Holiday Social 2014 Photos

Join us at Meetup.com

http://www.meetup.com/patuxent-toastmasters/

Patuxent Toastmasters Club meets on the 2nd and 4th Thursdays of the month, upstairs at the historic Oliver's Carriage House in downtown Columbia.

We suggest that you arrive at 7:15 PM for some socializing; our meetings begin promptly at 7:30 PM and end at approximately 9 PM.  

Oliver's Carriage house is located at 5410 Leaf Treader Way, Columbia, MD.

MAP

All are welcome.  Our club offers a friendly, supportive, and diverse learning environment.  We have members from many different walks of life, ages, ethnicities, religions, and nationalities. Although we meet in a community church, our club has no religious affiliations.

Are you looking for speaking tips....go to toastmasters international 

https://www.toastmasters.org/Resources/Public-Speaking-Tips

Member Experience

http://www.toastmasters.org/OtherImages/MemberExperienceImage.aspx

Being a member of Toastmasters International involves more than just showing up at meetings and giving a speech now and then.

Toastmasters membership is about being part of a supportive group of individuals in your local area who share the common goal of improving their communication and leadership skills.

From meeting roles and mentoring to speech contests and satellite programs, Toastmasters International offers a host of ways for members to progress and thrive.

Whether you’re a beginner or a long-standing member, the resources listed to the left will help make the most of the Toastmasters program.

Holiday 2012 Club photo

Leadership: From Toastmaster to Hit TV Show

http://www.toastmasters.org/ImageLibrary/MagazineSection/107MagazineImages/107TVShow.aspx

A contest speech led this former homemaker to
a new career as a professional organizer and TV host.

By Monique Cuvelier


Hellen Buttigieg is the embodiment of competence, strutting around messy houses with a sassy bob and an open face. She locks her huge brown eyes with a client’s and asks directly, but respectfully, “Do you really need this? Why? How does it make you feel when I take it away?” And very occasionally, when a person seems unreasonably attached to a shopping bag of old birthday cards or an ugly ashtray pilfered from a restaurant in Greece, she pulls out the tough love: “Are you going to give me trouble with this?” 

As the host of the Discovery Home Channel’s hit show Neat, Buttigieg provides clutter control and guidance to a new household every week. She’s something between an organizer and a headshrinker, with certifications as a professional organizer and as a life coach. She simultaneously cleans out closets while slowly uncovering subconscious “blocks” that make a person want to hoard junk or prevent them from putting their dirty clothes in the hamper. 

Her gentle leadership made a lifelong fan out of client Denise Fujiwara, who says Buttigieg “is a living example of what you can do with an affirmative attitude.” The Toronto-based choreographer was lost trying to sort out her home office to make room for a house renovation when she called in Buttigieg to help. As someone who runs her own choreography business and dance troupe, Fujiwara’s office is prone to clutter. “My office was a horrendous mess,” she says. She describes stacks of boxes, piles of unfiled papers, photographs, video tapes, press releases – essentially 15 years’ worth of disorder and confusion. 

“I’d tried to sort it out in the past, but I hadn’t had the skills to do it properly until I worked with Hellen. In about 6 hours, she did what I couldn’t do in 15 years,” she says. 

The two went around the room in an orderly way, starting at the door and working clockwise. “Occasionally, I’d get stuck on something, and she’d push me to make a decision,” says Fujiwara. “She pushed through, and in the end I felt euphoric to be relieved of all that stuff.” 

Buttigieg unloads stuff with a dancer’s grace and a politician’s diplomacy. Anyone would think she was born taking charge of people’s unruly environs, teaching them how to be better organized. In a way, that’s true. She says she was always organized, even as a teenager, when most kids live among piles of laundry, music collections and notebooks. She was also always a confident speaker. In grammar school, she was the girl who narrated the school plays. 

In fact, Buttigieg moves and speaks so naturally in front of the camera and with such calm assertiveness, no one would guess that not long ago she was at a loss for what to do with her life. 

“I had been out of the workforce for almost 10 years as a stay-at-home mom, but I lacked confidence, and I didn’t know what to do,” she says from her home in Oakville, a suburb of Toronto, Canada. 

She graduated from Seneca College in Toronto with a degree in radio and television broadcasting, and worked briefly as an administrator and fitness instructor. But then she had two children and took off nearly 10 years from work to raise them. Those 10 years at home had slowly whittled away her confidence as a businessperson, but she still wanted to launch a new career – and have some adult conversation. Her solution? In 1999, she joined City Centre Toastmasters. 

“Toastmasters changed my life,” she says. 

She means that in the most literal sense. It started with one of the first lessons any new Toastmaster learns: talk about what you know. Buttigieg started writing speeches about what she knew, and as someone who was naturally neat, she talked about organizing. And then at one contest she gave a speech called “Simple Simon” about simplifying your life by letting go of clutter, and it launched a new career. 

“Giving speeches is a journey of self-discovery,” she says. “How often in life do people really listen to us? At Toastmasters, people are truly listening; they’re not thinking about what they’ll say back. It’s a safe place to speak, so I could use my speeches to work out what resonated with the audience.” 

And also what resonated with her. That speech was the nugget that now sits at the center of her professional life. In fact, she still uses parts of the same speech today when she gives presentations: “If you would like to get a taste of the simple life, don’t let stuff complicate it. Commit to following these three simple steps: If you don’t use it, lose it; if you don’t need it, don’t buy it; and when you bring one item in, take one item out.” 

This would become her mantra in several ways. It sparked her desire to become a life coach and also tapped into her abilities as an organizer. Starting her own organizing business, called WeOrganizeU, helped pay for the life-coaching certification. Soon, a group of producers approached her about a new show that would blend her gifts for tidying up with her ability to lead people, and by 2004 Neat hit the North American airwaves. 

Buttigieg credits Toastmasters with more than just sparking a good idea; she also says she honed her skills as a leader and built confidence. Shalini Alleluia, president of City Centre Toastmasters, says Buttigieg faced a short learning curve thanks to her take-charge attitude. 

“Hellen had lots of energy and was articulate and vibrant,” Alleluia says. “She always smiled and was willing to try anything.” 

Alleluia says even though Buttigieg was a new member, she asked her to chair a speech contest and encouraged her to assume meeting roles. Soon Buttigieg was helping others to be better speakers. 

“I think Hellen was more of a mentor to other people than other people being a mentor to her,” Alleluia says. “She has a charisma that makes people want to follow her and to be like her in personality and capability. She’s a good listener, and she always pays attention to the evaluation notes. I once told her she was very loud and didn’t have expression in her delivery, and she really listened.” 

Like any good Toastmaster, Buttigieg is still seeking advice on how to improve. She still asks Alleluia for feedback on her presentations and episodes of the TV show. “I’m honest, and I’ll tell her what I thought the show lacked or what I learned,” says Alleluia. 

While Alleluia coaches Buttigieg to improve some public speaking skills, her student is working toward a broader purpose. “I’m a teacher,” she says. “I feel that whether I’m organizing or coaching or speaking, there’s still that element of wanting to pass on the information I know to improve other people’s lives.” 

Read The Toastmaster on Your iPad!


http://www.toastmasters.org/iPadMag Access the Toastmasters International iPad® app by following these steps:

1. Go to the Apple® App Store and search for “Toastmasters International.”

2. Select the blue “TI” app.

3. Download the app by tapping the down-facing arrow inside the small cloud icon. Then tap the OPEN
 button.

4. Sign in with the username and password that you use on the Toastmasters International website.

5. Tap the Library icon at the bottom of the screen.

6. Select a month’s issue to download.

7. Instructions for using the Toastmaster app can be found on the second page.

To automatically download new issues, go to your settings, click on the “iTunes and App Stores” tab, and turn on Automatic Downloads. You’ll receive an alert as each new issue becomes available.

The digital magazine will soon be available on other popular tablets and mobile devices.

During an energy healing session, Taruna facilitates the body’s natural self-healing ability by promoting a state of relaxation and release of stress. As a result, Taruna’s clients have reported improvements in many different physical, mental, and emotional challenges. Taruna has had a life-long interest in healing, and supporting clients in bringing greater peace, joy, and wellness into their lives. She enjoys providing these services to both adults and children.

results.description:
***NOTE:  ADEQUATE WATER SUPPLY AND BOWL ARE REQUIRED FOR YOUR DOG.***

WHERE TO MEET

Friday is supposed to be 71 & sunny, 83% humidity at 8:00 a.m.  With the rains behind us, let's gather the dogs and go to the river in King's Contrivance.  Take Eden Brook Drive across Guilford Road and turn left into the Amherst House lot at 7251 Eden Brook Drive.  Go all the way to the back of the parking lot for Amherst House to meet at the trail head in the field.  This is a paved trail with one or two major uphills but it's very doable.  (However, if you get winded easily, have COPD, etc., can't go a couple hours without a bathroom, please consider joining us on another hike.)  This hike is about 1.5 miles.  We may be able to let the dogs get their paws wet in the river, depending on the water level, so bring towels to dry his or her paws.

SAFETY & COURTESY

Please bring water and a bowl for your dog to drink on the trail. Please plan to arrive a few minutes earlyin order for the dogs to sniff and form their pack. They like having everyone sniffed out before we depart.  If you cannot make the meetup, please change your RSVP and/or leave a comment.

                                                                 Photo by Susan Azama

PLEASE READ:

Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for you to meet friendly people with friendly dogs on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that:

•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests. 

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a leash (six foot fixed length) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)

Look forward to seeing you and your doggies there!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for a small silver car with "Tigerlily" plates, and a sable & white collie.  We'll meet by the big tree in the corner in the shade.
results.name: Let's have a tenth of July Walk at King's Contrivance!

results.description:
We’ll launch from Jonas Green Park on the Severn River and paddle to the Chesapeake Bay. Then we’ll paddle with the tide up to Sandy Point State Park where we’ll stop for lunch. After lunch we’ll return with the tide to Jonas Green. Both Jonas Green and Sandy Point parks have bathrooms with running water :-)

Please plan to arrive in plenty of time to have your boat and gear ready to launch by 10:30 AM. . Expect to paddle about 13 miles. We should return to Jonas Green before 4:00 PM.

This is not a beginner paddle. We may encounter challenging conditions on the bay so you must have the skills and kayak appropriate for such conditions. You should be able to maintain a 3.5-mph pace and be comfortable paddling in choppy conditions. You must wear a sprayskirt and be able to perform a wet exit. Your kayak must be at least 14 feet long with sealed bulkheads. Contact me (Ben) if you have any questions.

On this and other CKA paddles you are required to wear a PFD and bring a whistle. Bring plenty of water to drink and stay hydrated, pack a lunch and wear a hat and sunscreen.

There are no rental kayaks available for this event.

Tides for Annapolis[masked]
1:14 am high tide ( 1.6 ft. )
7:23 am low tide ( 0.7 ft. )
12:46 pm high tide ( 1.3 ft. )
7:13 pm low tide ( 0.0 ft. )

The tide will be in our favor both ways.

Kayaking involves known and unanticipated risks including physical injury and death that cannot be eliminated without jeopardizing the essential quality of the sport. Group organizers and leaders and other members cannot pay continuous attention to all participants. Participants must be responsible for their own safety. Don’t overestimate your skills and abilities. Take instructional courses to learn about paddling technique, safety, self-rescue and hypothermia. Be aware of the tides, currents and weather conditions that will affect your safety on the days you paddle. Cooperate with group organizers, leaders and other members to insure your own safety as well as the safety of others and make it the fun, enjoyable day on the water it should be.
results.name: Jonas Green to Sandy Point and Back

RSVPs open on June 15th at 9:00 PM!

This trip has us paddling on the St Mary's River from the St Mary's College boat ramp to Tippity Witchity Island and back for a total paddle distance of about 8 miles.

The actual attendance limit for this paddle is 30 paddlers.  6 spots have been set aside for people who will be renting kayaks.  If you are a renter on the waiting list I will move you to the attending list.   Those spots not filled by renters 24 hours before the paddle will be filled with members on the waiting list who have paid the voluntary dues.  Everyone has the same chance to sign up for the first 24 slots.

Basically the idea is to paddle from the St Mary's College boat ramp in the afternoon and then go to the free St. Mary's College Concert afterward before heading home.  Of course, if you can't stay... we understand.  But if you can stay, plan to bringing a picnic dinner (including wine, beer or the beverage of your choice) for the concert after the paddle.  We also discovered a number of food vendors on site and only brought beverages.  But, they do have beer, wine, and liquor vendors as well.  The information about the concert is listed below.

July 10:The Music of Gerorge Frederick Handel: Sweatin’ to the Oldies


Larry Vote, guest conductor

Jeffrey Springer, tenor

Jeffrey Silberschlag, trumpet soloist

    River Concert Series Choir

Overture to Alcine

Aria des Oronte from Alcine (tenor)

“Sound an Alarm” from Judas Machabeus (tenor)

Concerto for 2 Violins HMV 330

Entrance of the Queen of Sheba

Coronations Anthems: The King Shall Rejoice,

Zadoc the Priest

Concerto for Trumpet n D

Overture to Xerxes

aria from Xerxes:

Ombra Mai Fu (tenor)

From Messiah:

Comfort Ye, Every Valley Shall be Exalted

(tenor solos)

And the Glory of the Lord

Hallelujah Chorus


Yes this is all happening on a Friday so you need to be able to take off or play hooky.  Point Look out is also a bit of a hike at around 100 miles (St Mary's City only saves 10 Miles) from the Baltimore area.  The time is tentative but we will probably be starting sometime a little bit after lunch.

We will meet at St Mary's College boat launch at 1:00 pm for a 1:30 pm on the water time.

The kayak rental cost for this event is $55.00.  Members who have paid the voluntary annual dues receive  a $5.00 discount on all kayak rentals.  Please be sure to answer the rental question when you RSVP to reserve a boat.


The concert starts at 7:00 pm. We should have plenty of time to load kayaks and relax before the drive up to St Mary’s City.

http://www.smcm.edu/riverconcert/

Some of us are planning on camping at Point Lookout State Park for the weekend.  There are a few of us planning on attending the St Mary's Paddle on Friday, the concert on Friday night,  Jake's Tiki Paddle at Solomon's Island on Saturday or a paddle around Point Lookout, and the Mallows Bay on Sunday.  This isn't a formal camping trip.  We will just all try to camp together and have a good time.  As of now I have sites reserved for us already in the Greens Point loop sites.  This year we opted for the the more expensive electric sites because they are near the water and there aren't as many bitey insects there!  We can put 2-3 tents on each site.  We might have to park some cars at the overflow site.  I may decide to go down Thursday night, earlier, if others are interested.  Price per person will be based on the number of people per site.  It should be about $15 per person per night.

results.description:
Please sign-up for this Potluck at:
http://www.perfectpotluck.com/meals.php?t=QKMI9075

First Unitarian Church of Baltimore's ADORE: A Dialogue on Race and Ethnicity

Friday, July 10, 2015, 6 to 9 pm

First Unitarian Church of Baltimore, Enoch Pratt Parish Hall , 1 W. Hamilton St. , Baltimore, MD 21201

At our last gathering on June 12, 2015 we watched 3 compelling TED Talks: Two by Clint Smith: How to raise a black son in America and The danger of silence, and one by Verna Myers: How to overcome our biases? Walk boldly toward them. We engaged in a soul-searching exercise about when we have mattered and when we have felt marginalized. Finally, we discussed what it means to belong in the Beloved Community and how we can work toward true multicultural integrity, justice and inclusion.

This time we will have a panel of Baltimoreans from around town, presenting snapshots of who we are and where we live. What do we know about our own neighborhoods? Are we ready to see Baltimore in a new light? Please bring a friend and join in some real talk.

Please contact me for more information--or just come with an open mind and spirit.

Peace,
Melissa Feliciano (410)[masked]

Co-facilitated by Paula Cole Jones, All Souls Church and Unitarian Universalist Association
Reverend David Carl Olson, First Unitarian Church of Baltimore
Reverend Doreion Colter, President of the Board
CJ Austin, JC Faullk, and Melissa Feliciano
https://www.ted.com
https://m.facebook.com/anendtoignorance?

results.description:
Like clockwork, the 2nd Friday of each month, same time, same place (at the Park Heights Community Health Alliance).  

By popular demand, we’ll use the same format as before:  a documentary video excerpt edited down to the best 20 minutes (which documentary? - it’s a surprise!).  Followed by a short educational presentation by Yours Truly, Dr. Joe (please call me “Joe”). 

By the time this event rolls around we will have announced the dates for our new TWICE-a-month in-person meeting schedule!   AS WELL AS a new series of conference calls, several per month, to keep in touch with one another and provide tips, tricks, help and support for those who want it.   We’ll include everyone who wants to talk by phone by scheduling as many conference calls as needed.  Stay tuned for details!     

By this time I expect some people will have started checking their “dry weight”  (weighing in the morning before getting dressed, and after emptying the bladder, for a highly reproducible measurement).   For those who want to share their progress this way - either confidentially with the organizer, with the whole group, (or not at all), we know that monitoring your progress in this way HELPS with weight loss!  

BTW, We found bathroom scales for $16 with free shipping (to those with an Amazon Prime account; I have one);  we’ll make those available, along with some other time-saving kitchen devices.  

(FYI, this meetup is Not JUST for people who want to lose weight). 

At the last few meetings there have been more and more enthusiastic Beginners, a trend I expect will continue.  Local health providers are getting the word and referring more of their patients.  These new folks don’t quite know what to expect, have never really tried a plant-based diet, let alone healthy food in some cases.  But they’re enthusiastic and motivated to address their diabetes, obesity, cholesterol, hypertension, etc. etc. - and They've Come To The Right Place!

These folks mix it up with others who are a little more experienced with preparing DELICIOUS, easy healthy food.  This way, we get a great dialogue, and some coaching, going on. 

All are encouraged to contact me for questions, help or support at[masked], or joeadamsmd [at] gmail.com).   Many other participants want to serve as coaches as well.   

Wherever you are in the spectrum of lifestyle change, novice or expert, this will be a fun, educational, and rewarding experience - and it might save your life.

Please bring along friends or family if you like. 

It is not mandatory to bring a dish to share, but we encourage it if you can, so we’ll be sure to have enough food for everyone.  (We always have).   If you’re new to this kind of cooking, or if it would be inconvenient for you to bring food, then just bring yourself.   If you do bring something, it must be vegan (free of meat, fish, fowl, eggs or dairy), and should not have a whole lot (if any) salt, oil or sugar.   If you bring something, please bring a piece of paper with your name (so we can ask for the recipe) and a list of ingredients.

NOTE:  Last meeting I passed around copies of  “Joe’s Favorite Go To Quick Meals”  which you can find in the Meetup page (http://www.meetup.com/Baltimore-Nutrition-As-Medicine-Potluck/) under ‘More’     then    ‘Files.’   These are a dozen of some of my favorite recipes that I have almost EVERY WEEK  . . . because they’re Easy and Delicious!    If any of them are not exciting enough for you at first, you can always add some nuts, sliced avocado, sweet Hoisin sauce, soy sauce, raisins, or even some store-bought Chow Mein Noodles (which are not healthy in any way, but they do make food taste great).   Heck, you could even add some olive oil if you must.   I think the recipes taste amazing as-is, but there’s no accounting for taste - and my tastes have already adapted to healthy whole-food.

Everything is free of charge, and there’s nothing to sell.  We’re passionate about helping others, and we get a lot out of it as well.  

I hope you'll join us!
results.name: New Documentary Excerpt, New Presentation - and You

Arepas are a kind of cornmeal flatbread and I think they're mostly common in Venezuela and Colombia. They're probably similar to papusas, except I've seen them made more into sandwiches than stuffed and served like pancakes with salsa. Both good! Mmmm... might need to find a good papuseria for another night! 

Anyway the website for this place is just gorgeous: http://almacocinalatina.com/#alma


I like it that this is the third place in Baltimore opened by the same woman who is from Caracas originally. http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/dining/bs-ae-alma-cocina-review-20150606-story.html

This is going to be tasty!
Hope to see you there,
Robin

results.description:
Here it is, the trip that started it all in the best wilderness areas around!

We have some more trails to clear in Dolly Sods and as well as Roaring Plains Wilderness Area, so we get Laneville Cabin for another weekend of hiking to some of the most beautiful Views, Falls and Swimming Holes around!  We will be doing another feast on Saturday night (Fried Turkey and all the fixings so I am charging each person $20 for food expenses for the main course on Saturday dinner and bacon and pancakes for sat. and sun. breakfast at the cabin,  to relive all the great experiences of the day and enjoy the front porch at the cabin once again! We can arrange carpooling as always but you must contact me at least 2 days before we leave as I must also coordinate food. The cabin has a full kitchen and bathroom with 12 bunk beds, but you will need to bring your sleeping bag or tent if you want to camp. Red Creek beckons again so we can finish our work in for the year and close out the summer with a bang! This is cross-posted from the Washington Backpackers Meetup Group. Directions are the same as the July 9, 2010 trip. Hiking will be moderate, but we can always go to more places if we finish early. My cell is[masked]-4848.  The pictures are from last Summer's Dolly Sods Trips to give you a "taste" of what is in store!

Laneville cabin GPS location:
[masked],[masked]
Link Google driving direction from Centreville Park&Ride:
http://goo.gl/maps/P8QB

Map of Dolly Sods and driving directions, information, and wilderness restrictions here:

http://www.fs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/stelprdb5152038.pdf

Please print a copy of the map and bring it with you.

Weather: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=39.020266643861994&lon=-79.32609558105469#.UdwOODvQqeR

results.description:
The movie showing Friday, July 10, 2015, is the critically acclaimed The Theory. of Everything.   Here's what reviewer Spencer Higham had to say: 

"The Theory of Everything is the story of the most brilliant and celebrated physicist of our time, Stephen Hawking, and Jane Wilde the arts student he fell in love with while studying at Cambridge in the 1960s.  Given just two years to live following the diagnosis of a fatal illness at 21 years of age, little was expected from Stephen Hawking, a bright but shiftless cosmology student.  He became galvanized, however, by the love of fellow Cambridge student, Jane Wilde, and he went on to be called the successor to Einstein, as well as a husband and father to their three children. Over the course of their marriage as Stephen's body collapsed and his academic renown soared, fault lines were exposed that tested the lineaments of their relationship and dramatically altered the course of both of their lives."

The film won an Oscar for Best Motion Picture.  Eddie Redmayne won both an Oscar and a Golden Globe for Best Performance by an Actor in A Leading Role for his portrayal of Hawking.

results.description:
*** If you are attending this practice, please don't forget to sign up on our website by clicking the "Sign Up" link at the top. ***


The BDBC open practices occur every Wednesday from 6:15 to 7:30 PM and Saturday mornings from 8:00 to 9:00. For those of you that have never participated in dragon boating before, here are a few handy things to know to make your experience more enjoyable:

- The club has never flipped a boat during practice so the odds of you going completely into the water are very low but please keep in mind that there can be a significant amount of splashing on board. Chances are good that you will get a bit wet while we're out there so you should dress accordingly. Wear clothes that you won't mind getting wet in.

- As far as footwear goes, some people like to paddle barefoot, some like to wear flip flops and others like water shoes of some sort. Sneakers and shoes like that are usually a bad idea since they can get pretty wet and uncomfortable pretty quickly. - Although the club normally tries to have a cooler available with bottled water, it's not a bad idea to bring a bottle with you to practice to take on the boat. During the summer months especially, it can get pretty warm out there and we like to hydrate regularly.

- The seats on the boat are not the softest in the world and your butt will most likely be a bit sore after practice. To soften the seat a bit, it is recommended that you bring some sort of pad. There are many different options that our club members use and some of the most popular are gardening knee pads and folded up bath mats. A bunched up towel will suffice as well. - Other handy items that you may want to bring with you are sunglasses, sunscreen, gloves and a hat.

- Life jackets and paddles are provided to everyone.

- There is not room on the boat to bring much else with you so please leave everything in your car/on land.

- There is a secure waterproof bag available to collect everyone's car keys when we get on the boat.

- The point of our open practices, is to get people familiar with the sport of dragon boating while demonstrating proper technique and timing. Our coaches are excellent at explaining the mechanics of paddling a dragon boat and working towards the ultimate goal of having all twenty paddlers working as a single unit to move as efficiently through the water as possible, all while having a whole lot of fun! More information can be found at <a>www.baltimoredragonboatclub.com.</a> Hope to see you there!
results.name: Open Practice

results.description:
Friday, 3:30pm:  The weather tomorrow morning is looking a bit iffy.  We will decide early tomorrow morning (perhaps around 7:30am) whether or not to walk.  KEY:  If you see NO new edits to this posting, assume the walk is STILL ON.

===================================

OK.  The weekday walkers can't have all the fun!!  Let's get our weekend walkers and pups together to do King's Contrivance as well!!


As a courtesy to all, if you make an RSVP, and your plans change, please change your RSVP to not attending, so someone else can join.  If your plans change on Saturday morning, or you are running late, call my mobile,[masked]-6186.  Thanks.

***NOTE:  ADEQUATE WATER SUPPLY AND BOWL ARE STRONGLY ENCOURAGED FOR YOUR DOG.***

WHERE TO MEET

Take Eden Brook Drive across Guilford Road and turn left into the Amherst House lot at 7251 Eden Brook Drive.  Go all the way to the back of the parking lot for Amherst House to meet at the trail head in the field.  This is a paved trail with one or two major uphills but it's very doable.  (However, if you get winded easily, have COPD, etc., can't go a couple hours without a bathroom, please consider joining us on another hike.)  This hike is about 1.5 miles.  

SAFETY & COURTESY

Please bring water and a bowl for your dog to drink on the trail. Please plan to arrive a few minutes early in order for the dogs to sniff and form their pack. They like having everyone sniffed out before we depart. 

                                                                 Photo by Susan Azama

PLEASE READ:

Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for you to meetfriendly people with friendly dogs on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that:

•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests. 

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a leash (six foot fixed length) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)

Look forward to seeing you and your doggies there!

results.description:
Want to try out trail running without the pressure of having to keep a certain pace??  Or just want a casual paced run/walk in the woods??  Come on out and join us! 


We'll keep a slow pace running, walking/resting as the group needs, and no one left behind (and we mean that!).

These trails are technical and challenging with several steep climbs, rocks, roots, loose dirt, and uneven surfaces.  To make up for all of the hard stuff, there is also a good amount of flat and downhill sections.  We’ll also be sharing the trails with mountain bikers, hikers, and other runners.  

The distance is between 3.5 - 4.5 miles total.  Time will be around an hour.

Trail Description:

The Soapstone trail is about 3 miles, out and back. It has several hills and climbs, creek crossings, and a bit of asphalt running. Most of the trail is wooded and there are bathrooms and water fountains mid-way. There will be some water crossing, dirt and muddy areas, rocks, and sticks...so please wear shoes you don't mind getting dirty or wet.  We can also hit the Bull Run trail for 1 extra mile.

Parking:

Parking is available at the Park and Ride in Catonsville (intersection of Rolling Road/MD 166 and 195) or at the trail head (just across the street).  We will meet up at the trail head, look for the group of runners.

Hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: We will gather at the trail head (across Rolling Rd. from the Park and Ride)
results.name: Beginner Trail Run/Walk - Patapsco Soapstone and Bull Run Trail (Catonsville)

results.description:
Ok, get your mind out of the gutter.  :-)  What were you thinking?!?!

*** 8:30am Meetup - Exxon 3384 Fort Meade rd. Laurel, md. (Near 198 & 295)**


We're off to Pennsylvania once again.


Let's tour the Intercourse Pretzel Factory! $3.50/pp  Riding time is about 3:45 round trip from Joppa start point.  No highways from the start.  However, the 8:30a group leaving from Laurel to Joppa will be taking some highway and will have the Harbour tunnel toll $3 EZ/ $4 cash.

[A visit to our pretzel factory should convince you there still is something for nothing in today’s world.

Only a handful of companies still hand twist a hard pretzel. It is a lot of work to bake pretzels the old-fashioned way. The taste & texture is unique.

On our FREE 10-15 minute tour, we explain how we make our hard pretzels and then give you a piece of dough so you can learn to twist a pretzel.

When you are finished, the dough is discarded as there is no sanitary way to bake your pretzel.

You are awarded with an official pretzel twister sticker.

Our production is just 100 pounds a day. Everything we make is sold in our store or by mail order. To the best of our knowledge, there are only six factories besides us that still twist pretzels by hand.]  Bring a bungee for some souvies!


We will follow the tour up with a lunch stop and then return.  We should return around 4pm give/take.  LET'S ROLL!!
results.name: Sturgis-Intercourse Tour!   Do You Prefer Soft or Hard?

results.description: A rain garden is a special, water loving garden that helps soak up rain water from your roof or driveway. It is designed to capture water from a 1” rain storm and is planted in low spots in your yard to absorb and filter the water then slowly filter it back into the ground. Rain Gardens are planted with beautiful, native flowers, grasses and even trees that will beautify your yard while reducing stormwater impacts. They also provide habitat for wildlife, beneficial insects such as lady bugs, and pollinators like butterflies. You can learn more about them, help to plant one, and find out more about how GVC can help you with your own installation at this Rain Garden Workshop at Wilson Point!

CoderDojo is a free, volunteer-led, community based programming club for young people between 7 and 17, where they can  learn how to code, develop websites, apps, programs, games and explore technology in an informal and creative environment.

After a great inaugural event on May 30th, this is one of two summer sessions we will be holding in July and August  before we kick off the full fall agenda. Join us for a fun filled morning where we will continue to introduce Coder Dojo to the parents and the kids and gain an understanding fro group needs. 

For this event, we will plan to hold two group sessions - one is for those newer to programming and it is intended to re-introduce and build off of some of the basic elements the kids learned in the first session. 


The second group will be focused on supporting growth for more experienced coders and we will continue to push forward on some of the projects the group outlined at our last event.

If you missed the first meeting, please know that you can join in any time and we will always work to help ensure your child gets up to speed and feels included.  

Some light food and drinks will be provided. While we will have a few extra laptops available, we do ask that the kids come with a laptop for this initial event. 

Interested in helping? Just let us know as mentors and volunteers are always needed and welcome (older kids are welcome to join and help as a mentor or volunteer)

Thank you to ReefPoint Group (www.reefpointgroup.com/) for volunteering their beautiful space and support as we get this group off the ground.

If you have any questions, please contact David Blackburn at[masked] or Dave Gilinson at [masked]

results.description:
RSVPs will be open on June 15th at 9:15 PM. 


Point Lookout Paddle

The actual attendance limit for this paddle is 30 paddlers.  6 spots have been set aside for people who will be renting kayaks.  If you are a renter on the waiting list I will move you to the attending list.   Those spots not filled by renters 24 hours before the paddle will be filled with members on the waiting list who have paid the voluntary dues.  Everyone has the same chance to sign up for the first 24 slots.  Chuck will actually be heading up to Solomon's Island to provide rentals for Jake's Tiki Bar Paddle. But Kimmie will have boats available to rent.  Sign up quickly, because Chuck will have rentals at both sites and they will go fast!!!!


We're at that time of year where weather changes rapidly anywhere near the Chesapeake Bay.  We will do our best to plan paddle options that take everyone's skill level into account but depending on the weather you probably should be willing to deal with a little chop.

We will meet at Point Lookout State Park boat launch for a 10:30 AM on the water time, or you can stop by our camp sites at Greens Point Loop sites 94.  Yes, we are camping.  If interested, please let Kimmie know so she can make sure she gets enough sites.  We are camping and paddling Friday, Saturday, and Sunday!

The boat launch is past the causeway on the right hand side. It is a soft beach launch site. There are bathroom facilities available and a small park store on site.

We will explore Canoy Lake and then into Hall Pond. There is a small bridge to go under and then on to a nice beach area take a break. We will then return towards the boat launch. If the weather and winds are favorable we will then paddle out the lake into the Potomac River and along the beach to the Point Lookout Lighthouse.

We should be on the water at least 3-4 hours, but we will make final plans on that day based on weather and activities.

The kayak rental cost for this event is $55.00.  Members who have paid the voluntary annual dues receive  a $5.00 discount on all kayak rentals.  Please be sure to answer the rental question when you RSVP to reserve a boat.


Again, if you are interested in camping, let Kimmie know!
results.name: Point Lookout Paddle

Saturday’s 1 ½-mile parade features a stream of floats, eye-catching costumes, and the hip-swaying sounds of soca music.

Parade Date & Time: Saturday, July 11, 2015; 12 Noon – 5:00 PM
Parade Start: 900 E 33rd Street, Baltimore MD 21218
Parade End: Clifton Park, Baltimore MD 21213

Beginning at the 900 block of 33rd Street in Baltimore, Maryland, the parade proceeds east on 33rd Street, then turns right on The Alameda and continues south across Harford Road to enter Clifton Park via St. Lo Drive.

The parade is expected to last approximately five (5) hours with the last participating band crossing the Harford and St. Lo Drive intersection by 5:00 pm.

Following the parade, a festival continues at Lake Clifton Park until 10:00 pm.

results.description:
(Public Event!) Diplomacy differs from the majority of war games in several ways:

-Players do not take one turn each, instead all players secretly write down their moves after a negotiation period, and then all moves are revealed and put into effect simultaneously.

-Social interaction and interpersonal skills make up an essential part of the game's play.

-The rules that simulate combat are strategic, abstract, and simple—not tactical, realistic, or complex—as this is a diplomatic simulation game, not a military one.

-Combat resolution contains no random elements — no dice are rolled, no cards are drawn.

We have to have 7 players to play this game. The 7 players are firm so if you are not sure if you will be able to attend please RSVP No as soon as possible. This is a long game 6+ hrs not including the instruction in the beginning.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i0RLSs7IL9I

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g844EvintEc

results.description:
Refresh and rejuvenate with a free community service initiative to introduce people to breathing & meditation techniques that have a calming effect on the mind and reduce stress. In this 60-minute interactive session, participants develop insight on how to reduce negative emotions - anger, regret, sadness, anxiety and fear - that eat up our energy and time putting an unnecessary burden on our efforts. This workshop is also an introduction to the Art of Living Course.

During the workshop participants will experience:


• Breathing techniques that increase energy and vitality


• A guided meditation


• The connection between our breath, emotions, mind, body & the Self


• Discussion about the tendencies of the mind

Participants will be introduced to tools to chart a new course to healthier, happier, stress-free living.

results.description: Lolita is an amazing individual, and we invite you to learn more about her. An orca whale captured in 1970 off the coast of Washington State, Lolita is the sole survivor out of six young orcas captured and ripped away from their families that day. Lolita is currently captive at the Miami Seaquarium. Activists are fighting for Lolita's release and reunion with her mother and extended family, who still live freely. The recent news that the Miami Seaquarium will be sold to Palace Entertainment opens up new questions about Lolita's future. Join us to hear Lolita's story. We're thrilled to announce that Tim Gorski, the film's Director, will join us for Q & A following the screening! Mr. Gorski may join us remotely, or perhaps in person!
results.name: Film Screening: "Lolita: Slave to Entertainment"

results.description:
!! - Lacross Tournamet took over the park.  We are at my place and willl be there and behind the building.


So it's summer; let's go outside and play some games, eat, and have fun with members old and new.

Feel free to bring any games you might have for the outdoors.  I have a croquet set and can teach people how to play it if you never have before.  I also have some frisbees and soccer balls for a relaxing back-and-forth for either sport.  There are goals set up on the fields for practicing your scoring kick!  I don't have a football, so if someone wants to bring one.  I will have my pump with me and can inflate any balls people bring.


We will meet at Blandair Park.  There is a huge place to sit and retreat from the sun (only 1, so it will be easy to spot as it's directly in front of the parking lot), and I will have food and drinks for everyone, but anyone is welcome to bring any food they wish.  Even if you don't want to participate in any games, you can still relax and hang out with other fellow members.


Blandair Park isn't that big, but we can play next to the shelter.  And there are also 3 football/soccer fields with lots of space, too.


If you've been to my place in Columbia before, this is less than a mile from my house (so when dusk sets and the park closes, anyone is welcome to come to my place and watch anime).  When on Tamar Drive, take the first right on Montgomery Road, and keep driving straight until you see the park (Montgomery becomes Oakland Mills).   If coming from 29, the GPS will take you down Thunder Hill, the first left on Soho, and the first right on Oakland Mills (the park is where Oakland Mills Road begins/ends).


Also, no alcohol is allowed and there is no basketball or tennis court.  There are bathrooms and a children's playground, however.

results.description:
From the whispering shadows of haunted Ustalav an ancient evil rises to grip the world in a new age of horror!

Amid the mists of this land of dark superstition and dread secrets stand both those who would defy the return of evil and those who would seek its terrible favor. Can the heroes discern their allies from their enemies in time to save a tortured realm from a tyrant’s return? Pathfinder’s darkest and most frightening campaign ever sets the heroes against the agents of Golarion’s most notorious villain, the Whispering Tyrant, in a terrifying trek across a land of lurking horror and ancient mysteries.

Party Details
Arrival Times:

5:00pm
5:30pm *500 People can check in during one check-in time.
Check In:

Check-in with the Holi Color Festival staff at the Registration tent. They will give you the cool free stuff we promised you. After you have checked in, security will allow you to go through the gates to enter the festival. Bring your photo ID and signed waiver to check-in.
EDM Paint Rave: Sign Up NOW!
Saturday 5:00pm to 9:00pm.

Minimum Age to Attend:

There is none. We want everyone to feel the love.
What do ya get?
Holi Color Festival Sack Pack
Holi Color Festival $10 voucher towards merchandise
Bag of Holi Color
Too Cool for School Sunglasses
Sick Live entertainment
Paint Party! (bbq, beer, food, color & paint will be for sale)
Tons of new friends covered in color and paint that as crazy as you!
Hugs from Strangers

Ticket Price:

Steal: $19 until Jan 7, 2015
Discount: $29 from Jan 8, 2015 to March 11, 2015
Early: $39 from March 12, 2015 to April 29, 2015
Late: $49 from April 30, 2015 to June 10, 2015
Procrastinator: $69 from June 11, 2015 to July 8, 2015


No registration will be accepted after 11:59pm on July 8, 2015 (pacific std time)

Overnight Camping:
Wanna camp out overnight? Pitch a tent!
Make Holi Color Festival a weekend get-away!
A campsite fits 6 party animals! (You and 5 other friends)
Camping is on Friday and Saturday nights only
Please arrive on Friday between 6:30pm – 9pm and pack up on Sunday by 12pm.
Camping Price: 1 price * 2 nights * 6 people
Steal: $90 until Jan 7, 2015 (which equals $7.5 per person per night)
Discount: $95 from Jan 8, 2015 to March 11, 2015
Early: $105 from March 12, 2015 to April 29, 2015
Late:
$115 from April 30, 2015 to June 10, 2015
Procrastinator: $125 from June 11, 2015 to July 8, 2015
I registered for a campsite. Do all my friends staying at my campsite also need to register to go camping?

Nope they won’t need to register to camp. You can collect money from them to stay at your campsite. When you arrive, please go to the camping check in and have your registration number and photo id ready so the Holi Color Festival staff can check you in and direct you where to go. Please remember each campsite is allowed to have only 6 campers so if your friends are arriving at different times, please give them your registration number so they can also check in and get to your campsite. How big is a campsite?

Approximately 20’ x 20’
Nights all you party animals can camp!

Friday and Saturday night. Sorry no camping any other night.
Camping Arrival Times:

Friday night between 6:30pm-9pm
Saturday between 7am-9pm

There will be a staff member at the camping check in to check you in and direct you to your reserved campsite.
How can I have my campsite next to my friend's campsite?
Arrive at camping check-in at the same time and let the staff know. If you arrive at different times, it might be difficult for you guys to be next to each other.
Camp Fires:

Please do not start your own campfire because of the risk this location has of a wildfire. You will be asked to leave if you start a camp fire.
Spread the Word:

Click here to download the 2015 Maryland/DC flyer and give it to every person you know or post it in your office, gym, college dorm, bathroom... wherever.

Event Photos:

Got some awesome photos? Post ‘em on the Holi Color Festival Facbook page!
Go For It Photo is bringing in a professional team of photographers to capture you at the height of your intensity, lunacy and just plain craziness out in the pit this year. Their highly skilled team will catch you at your finest moments. And of course they will be available to you a few days after the festival to purchase. Their prices are quite reasonable compared to others we've seen and the quality is AWESOME! Nothing better than a great shot for a never to be forgotten weekend. Would you ever go to Mardi Gras, Wood Stock, or Burning Man without getting photos? Check them out!

results.description:
Come join Go Social and BNG on a bar crawl in Hampden!

Bar crawl will start at the Eightbar, which is in the back of Atomic Books. From there we'll move on to The Hon Cafe, De Kleine Duivel, and then get some fries at La Garage. We hope you join us.


If you're new to Baltimore, Hampden is one of Baltimore's most distinctive neighborhoods.  Going on a bar crawl is a great way to familiarize yourself with this neighborhood.

If you've been to Hampden you know how much fun "The Avenue" can be and you should come out and say hello :)

Special shout out to Dave from BNG for getting us some great specials! (We will have to give you a wristband in order for you to get the special)

6:00-7:00 Eightbar (Atomic Books) $1 off drinks

7:00-8:00 David's First and Ten $1 off drafts

8:00-9:00 Cafe Hon - They offered their normal happy hour menu, which is the following:

Onion Rings $6, Tater Tots $6, Cheesy Fries $6, Beef Sliders $6, Hummus Platter $6, Bawler’s Best Wings (Hot or Old bay) $6, Hot Crab Dip $7, Kitchen Sink Nachos $9 Natty Boh Drafts $2 Domestic Bottles $2.50, $3 Select Drafts.

results.description:
Bring your prayers and intentions along with your drums or other percussion instruments.

A drum circle is a fun experience that is accessible to anyone who wants to participate regardless of age or experience level. The goal is to achieve oneness with a group, not rhythmic perfection. Shamanism is the oldest spiritual belief system on earth. Drumming has been a method of group healing and achieving unity since the beginning of time. Studies have shown that drumming accelerates physical healing, boosts the immune system and produces feelings of well-being.

The drum circle will be held every 2nd Saturday of the month from 7:00 to 8:30 with time for socializing afterwards. Light refreshments will be provided. 

$5 - $10 voluntary donation. No one will be turned away if finances are an issue. All are welcome.

We encourage you to bring your drum or other instruments, but if you don't have any we have a few extras available.
results.how_to_find_us: Off of York Road in Timonium next to Nautilus Diner

The ASGT season of intrigue continues with a musical comedy about chasing your dreams…and not getting caught! Catch Me If You Can is a high-flying criminal caper based on the hit DreamWorks film and the incredible true story that inspired it. 

A teenager named Frank W. Abagnale, Jr. runs away from home in search of a glamorous life. With nothing more than his boyish charm, a big imagination, and millions of dollars in forged checks, Frank successfully poses as a pilot, a doctor, and a lawyer—living the high life and winning the girl of his dreams. But when this globe-trotting con artist catches the attention of FBI agent Carl Hanratty, Carl pursues Frank across the country. Along the way, the two forge an unlikely friendship and discover a surprising way to work together. 

Filled with jazzy music, high-energy dance numbers, and a riveting story, this big, bright new musical was created by a Tony Award-winning “dream team”, with a book by Terrence McNally (The Full Monty, Ragtime) and a swinging score by Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman (Hairspray).
results.name: Musical Theater: Catch Me If You Can!

results.description: This ride goes on all year long, weather permitting. When the temp is under 25 deg., we tend to wimp out. The ride starts at Harford and Argonne (where the side road goes down to the playground) at 6:20 am. They are usually punctual on the time. It is a fast casual ride - strong riders, but not racers and some are on hybrids or cyclocross. It loops the city, going through major parks for about 28 miles, stopping in South Baltimore for a break. It finishes around 9:00 am at Lake Montebello. Many people will hook up on the ride at different areas of the City - either 39th and Greenmount, or Druid Hill Park by the Conservatory: http://baltimore.about.com/od/parks/ss/druidhillconsv.htm

results.description:
Date:Sunday, July 12


Trip Leader:  Patty Hagan

Check in Time: 9:15

Check in Location: Atlantic Sailing Experience

Sailing (Half Day): 9:30 am – 1:00 pm.

Number of Sailors: 6

Cost: $36 SCWDC members;  $41 Guests

Reservations and advance payment required, click here.   

The Boat: SCWDC has half and full-day sails aboard the Caribbean Magic  a C&C 44</a> based out of <a href="https://www.google.com/maps/place/Atlantic+Sailing+Experience+LLC/@39.133226,-76.4990246,13z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x89b7fefa818d50b3:0xee1117d851b91c2d?hl=en">Pasadena, MD with Captain Larry Vazanno. For more information please visit: Atlantic Sailing Experience.


Weather: We sail rain or shine! Sails are cancelled only if there is severe weather or extreme heat as determined by the skipper in conjunction with the Bay Sail Coordinator.

What to Bring: Bring your lunch, water, sun glasses, hat and sun block and you’re ready for a great day. More information and directions will be emailed to you the week of the sail.

Overview: No experience is necessary! Captain Larry will gladly share his extensive knowledge. You can take the helm and help trim the sails, or just sunbathe on the bow if that’s your preference. Enjoy taking pictures or peering through the binoculars to see the beautiful osprey diving with their sharp talons to grab a fish to take back to the nest to quiet the peeping chicks. And as you sail out of the Patapsco River onto the Chesapeake Bay, you can see the Francis Scott Key Bridge and the buoy marking the location of where Key penned the Star Spangled Banner. After a great day of sailing, the fun continues with dinner at a local restaurant (separate cost).

Reminder: Advance payment is required. A RSVP to this Meetup is not sufficient to register for this event.

More Links

Weather

National Data Buoy Center, Francis Scott Key Bridge, MD

Atlantic Sailing Experience Photos

More than 14 days before the event, a $10 cancellation fee is assessed.

results.description:
Here's the info from the Barnes and Noble website:  "One Sunday in the spring of 1988, a woman living on a reservation in North Dakota is attacked. The details of the crime are slow to surface because Geraldine Coutts is traumatized and reluctant to relive or reveal what happened, either to the police or to her husband, Bazil, and thirteen-year-old son, Joe. In one day, Joe's life is irrevocably transformed. He tries to heal his mother, but she will not leave her bed and slips into an abyss of solitude. Increasingly alone, Joe finds himself thrust prematurely into an adult world for which he is ill prepared.

While his father, a tribal judge, endeavors to wrest justice from a situation that defies his efforts, Joe becomes frustrated with the official investigation and sets out with his trusted friends, Cappy, Zack, and Angus, to get some answers of his own. Their quest takes them first to the Round House, a sacred space and place of worship for the Ojibwe. And this is only the beginning."

results.description:
One of the best kept secrets here just north of Towson is the public access to a "protected" area of Loch Raven Reservoir park on the weekend.  On both Saturday and Sunday, park police close off Loch Raven Drive (some maps call it Loch Raven Rd.) between Morgan Mill Road and Providence Road. The road becomes a recreational area for walking, running, biking, and the like.  In the warmer months, many people picnic or just relax on blankets and chairs along the water.  The views of the water and the surrounding wooded areas are wonderful all year round.

It is an "out and back" hike, can't possibly get lost, bite off as much as you want to chew.

The total distance is approximately 3 and 1/2 miles which we complete in roughly 1 hour, so that you can probably be home before noon, if you want to. But also feel free to stay as long as you like.

 Loch Raven is city reservoir property. It, technically, is not a park at all. In other words, no potty facilities, no pavilions, etc. What you see is what you get. So......take care of business before you get there.

To get there, if you are travelling north on Dulaney Valley Rd. from the Beltway, the road splits just after crossing a large bridge over the lake. Dulaney Valley Rd. is the one that continues to the right toward the east. That's what you want. Don't go up the hill which is Jarrettsville Pike.

Travel on Dulaney Valley Road for roughly another mile or so. You will enter the park from the north. To do so, you bear right/make a right hand turn from Dulaney Valley Rd onto Loch Raven Drive at the corner where Peerce's Plantation/Landing/Grille (the name depends on who owns it this week; it's had some turnover in recent years) is located.  Peerce's address is 12460 Dulaney Valley Road 21131. If your GPS is telling you to go farther north on Dulaney Valley Rd past Peerce's, it's just plain wrong !!! Once you enter the park, the meeting place is about a mile down the road.

This hike will begin at the road closure gate at the corner of Loch Raven Drive and Morgan Mill Road. Parking is allowed on the west side of Loch Raven Drive and there is a sort of a parking lot on Morgan Mill Road.

When you see this sign, you've found the right place.  We'll meet right behind it, by where you see the guy/rock. 

Loch Raven Drive is a normal, well paved road, so there is no need for "off road" footwear unless you choose to get adventurous and challenge the rather steep hills that surround the lake.  That is certainly an option for those who are more experienced and confident.  However, I am not aware of any sanctioned, prepared trails in that area of Loch Raven and can't recommend it.  It would be free style.

I will not post cancellations because of the weather. I assume we're all capable of making that decision as each of us sees fit.

If you decide to respond "Yes" to this event and later change your mind for whatever reason, please,please go in and change your RSVP to a "No". That way, we know not to be waiting for you. Thanks.

So come join us on Sunday for a brisk walk in the park. It's a great way to clean out the cobwebs and start a Sunday.
results.how_to_find_us: Please read the directions below carefully. We do NOT meet at Peerce's. That's just a landmark along the way.
results.name: Loch Raven Beginner Hike---  ON YOUR OWN

Bring your unfinished socks that need attention! If you want to learn the magic loop, bring a circular needle that is at least 30" or longer. [The magic loop allows you to knit in the round with any size project, no matter how small.]If you have kitchener stitch questions, I recommend watching this video.


http://www.knittinghelp.com/video/play/kitchener-stitch


On Sunday, bring something you can use for practice.Other than turning the heel, many of these techniques are used for making gloves, mittens, hats, fingerless gloves, infinity scarves and other projects.

New to knitting? Want to learn? Want to crochet instead? Just want to network? All are welcome!

WE MEET EVERY SUNDAY AT PANERA.

results.description:
Join fellow iPhone and mobile photographers on a Historic Annapolis photo walk. As you likely know Annapolis is the capital of Maryland but it was also at one time the capital of the United States in 1783. Founded in 1695 as the capital of the Maryland Colony, Annapolis has thrived as an important port city and later as a seat of government for the county and state and is home to the US Naval Academy.


Architecturally the city has many unaltered grand 18th century buildings within a 10 minute walk as well as numerous 19th and 20th century buildings of different styles.

We will meet at the bottom of Main Street near the City Dock and follow a path up Main Street to the traffic circle around St. Anne’s Church to the State House and then down East Street towards the Naval Academy.

As with any photo walk, what you photograph is up to you. There will be plenty of opportunities for street photography, portraits, architecture, abstract, close-up and other styles too many to name!

The $5 contribution is voluntary to help support the cost of organizing this group. You can contribute what you wish in cash at the Meetup.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet near the Alex Haley Memorial at the base of the steps bythe water.
results.name: Historic Annapolis Photo Walk

You might get muddy on the trails, so dress accordingly.

results.description:
RSVPs will be open on June 15th at 9:30 PM!

Mallows Bay
Paddle the Ghost Fleet

The actual attendance limit for this paddle is 30 paddlers.  6 spots have been set aside for people who will be renting kayaks.  If you are a renter on the waiting list I will move you to the attending list.   Those spots not filled by renters 24 hours before the paddle will be filled with members on the waiting list who have paid the voluntary dues.  Everyone has the same chance to sign up for the first 24 slots.

If you look closely at the picture above you'll start to see the outlines of ships emerge.  While not even remotely the largest North American ship graveyard that some claim, Mallows Bay is the final resting place for a few hundred ships dating back to the civil war.  That's still a whole bunch of sunken ships.  Many if not most of them are wooden steamships built near the end of World War I that were never used in the World War I and were scuttled at Mallows Bay in the late 1920's.  The ships have created their own little ecosystems in the form of islands and reefs in this little bay on the Lower Potomac River.

The Potomac near Mallows Bay is a little over two miles wide.  So much of how this paddle happens depends on the weather and water conditions on that big wide open water the day of the paddle.  It is possible to paddle from the put in we are using, tour through the sunken ships of Mallows Bay and be back in less than a couple of miles.  Hopefully weather and water will cooperate and allow us to add some distance to that for a total of 8 to 10 miles.  Some of that will be out on the Potomac paddling upstream against the current in what might be a fair amount of chop.

Bring plenty to drink and stay hydrated and pack a lunch for a stop at beach somewhere along the Potomac.  At this beach, we can search for shark's teeth.  Last year we found many.

The kayak rental cost for this event is $55.00.  Members who have paid the voluntary annual dues receive  a $5.00 discount on all kayak rentals.  Please be sure to answer the rental question when you RSVP to reserve a boat.

Some of us are planning on camping at Point Lookout State Park for the weekend.  There are a few of us planning on attending the St Mary's Paddle on Friday, the concert on Friday night,  Jake's Tiki Paddle at Solomon's Island on Saturday or at Point Lookout, and the Mallows Bay on Sunday.  This isn't a formal camping trip.  We will just all try to camp together and have a good time.  If you are interested in camping, let Kimmie know I will try to reserve enough spots.  I already have 4 sites reserved!

RSVP opens on June 15th at 9:30 PM.
results.name: Mallows Bay - Paddle the Ghost Fleet

results.description:
A documentary on the late singer-songwriter Amy Winehouse, who died of alcohol poisoning in 2011.

Talking to Asif Kapadia can feel like talking to an obsessive; someone so fascinated by one thing that they have not only consumed all they could about their subject, but sworn to preserve the truth about them, too. That subject is Amy Winehouse. That truth is the complicated conjunction of circumstance and agency that led the singer to die from alcohol intoxication at the age of 27.

“There’s a point in the process where you can start correcting your interviewees because you know the story now. I know it,” he says. “I know when someone’s telling me something true and when they’re making it up. I know when they’re putting themselves in her life. Or, I’ll start saying to people who say they met Amy: ‘I don’t think you really met Amy. The person you describe, that’s not Amy, by that point she’d changed and I don’t know what you’re talking about.’”

A 43-year-old Londoner, Kapadia is the man behind Amy, a documentary that chronicles Winehouse’s tragic decline from bright-eyed prodigy to doomed tabloid obsession. Assembled from 100 interviews and incorporating 20 months of editing in a process that took three years in total, the film presents what feels like a true version of events. It is also incredibly moving.

https://youtu.be/A97-pQJD6Hw
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the lobby.
results.name: Amy   (d. Asif Kapadia)

results.description:
It's great to get outside and explore the natural world.  Why not keep track of what you find? Field Journals are notebooks where you record observations and then share what you've seen with other people.  Field Journals can include words, sketches, questions about what you see, and your thoughts about how your environment changes over time. They are tools that can help you better understand nature and yourself!

You don't need to be an artist or an expert to start keeping a field journal. During this trip, we'll head outdoors to Marshy Point Park to observe and track those observations in a journal.  If you're new to field journaling, Martha can offer guidance.  If you are experienced with keeping a field journal, that's fine. This is a chance to learn from other journal-keepers and expand your materials and methods.  

When: Sunday, July 12th, 1 - 4 pm      

Raindate: Sunday, July 26th.

Location: Marshy Point Park (We'll try a different trail from our last trip.)

Bring: Something to write with, and something to write on.  Nothing fancy. You're welcome to bring other art materials.

Dress: Dress for the weather.  Wear a hat for the sun and bring water to drink. Bring sunsreen and insect repellent if you need them.

Cost: $10 

Martha is a volunteer, so your money for these sessions will go directly to support the programs, the nature collections, and the building that make this kind of nature education possible.  Please consider becoming a member of the Natural History Society of Maryland by visiting <a>www.marylandnature.org.</a>

The instructor: Martha Stauss is a Senior Engineer specializing in GIS and Environmental Science with the Maryland Environmental Service.  She has taught Earth Science for local colleges and has special interests in wetland and estuarine ecology, plant taxonomy, environmental design, and planning. Martha spends as much time outside as she can.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet near the entrance to the nature center.
results.name: Field Journaling at Marshy Point Park
